How to compile Apache

... in OSX.

Organize

To keep from getting confused with other installations, the build process must be organized in such a way that is self-contained. To do this, create a build directory to house the Apache source files and an installation directory where compiled Apache files will be placed. 

mkdir -p ~/build/httpd    # for sources
mkdir -p ~/tools/httpd    # for compiled files

Do not install in /usr or /usr/local as the new installation could conflict/overwrite previous installations.

Get the source

Next, download the Apache source files. At the time of writing it is available from http://httpd.apache.org. Pick the gzipped (.gz) version.

Now, assuming the downloaded file went to ~/Downloads, extract the files and move them to the build directory. 

cd ~/Downloads
tar -xzvf httpd-2.4.4.tar.gz
mv httpd-2.4.4 ~/build/httpd
cd ~/build/httpd

Configure

From the build directory, the next step is now to configure compilation and installation settings. 

./configure --prefix=$HOME/tools/httpd

The --prefix option specifies where Apache will be installed.

Build

After configuring, the sources can now be compiled. Run make to compile Apache and generate the files to be installed.

make clean
make

This step may take some time...

Installation

Finally, Apache has been configured and built. All that's left is to install.

make install
